p:
Using the large-scale soil databases to indicate local-scale observations introduces uncertainties. To reduce this uncertainty, we compared the SOC density for the available site-depths from the two databases (Supplementary Fig. 5c), and excluded those with a relative difference (calculated as
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\left| {\frac{{{\rm{SOC}}_{{\rm{NCSCD}}} - {\rm{SOC}}_{{\rm{WISE}}}}}{{{\rm{SOC}}_{{\rm{NCSCD}}} + {\rm{SOC}}_{{\rm{WISE}}}}}} \right|$$\end{document}
SOC
NCSCD
-
SOC
WISE
SOC
NCSCD
+
SOC
WISE
) larger than 25%. This filtering process removes 105 site-depth SOC values, leaving 100 pairs of D-SOC NCSCD and 278 pairs of D-SOC WISE as shown in Fig. 1, spanning 184 sites (170 sites from RHST and 14 sites from IPY, Supplementary Fig. 1 red). For consistency, the excluded site-depths were also removed from the analysis of the other soil properties as shown in Supplementary Fig. 2.
